dt.t: When Caswall asked him to describe what he had seen …, he got very {wi}agitated{/wi} …
was so {wi}agitated{/wi} she could hardly speak

shortdef: troubled in mind : disturbed and upset

dt: {bc}to excite and often trouble the mind or feelings of {bc}{sx|disturb||}

dt.t: My presence did not appear to {wi}agitate{/wi} or irritate him as before, and he accepted my services quietly …
… trying to {wi}agitate{/wi} the old question of the embezzlement of the remains of the Confederate Treasury.

dt: {bc}to move with an irregular, rapid, or violent action

pt: {sc}shake{/sc} {sc}agitate{/sc} {sc}rock{/sc} {sc}convulse{/sc} mean to move up and down or to and fro with some violence. {sc}shake{/sc} often carries a further implication of a particular purpose.
{sc}agitate{/sc} suggests a violent and prolonged tossing or stirring.
{sc}rock{/sc} suggests a swinging or swaying motion resulting from violent impact or upheaval.

pt.t: the whole city was {it}rocked{/it} by the explosion

pt: {sc}convulse{/sc} suggests a violent pulling or wrenching as of a body in a paroxysm.

{sc}discompose{/sc} {sc}disquiet{/sc} {sc}disturb{/sc} {sc}perturb{/sc} {sc}agitate{/sc} {sc}upset{/sc} {sc}fluster{/sc} mean to destroy capacity for collected thought or decisive action. {sc}discompose{/sc} implies some degree of loss of self-control or self-confidence especially through emotional stress.

pt.t: {it}discomposed{/it} by the loss of his beloved wife

pt: {sc}disquiet{/sc} suggests loss of sense of security or peace of mind.
{sc}disturb{/sc} implies interference with one's mental processes caused by worry, perplexity, or interruption.
{sc}perturb{/sc} implies deep disturbance of mind and emotions.
{sc}agitate{/sc} suggests obvious external signs of nervous or emotional excitement.

pt.t: in his {it}agitated{/it} state we could see he was unable to work

pt: {sc}upset{/sc} implies the disturbance of normal or habitual functioning by disappointment, distress, or grief.

pt.t: the family's constant bickering {it}upsets{/it} the youngest child
his declaration of love completely {it}flustered{/it} her

et: Middle English {it}agitat{/it} "set in motion," borrowed from Latin {it}agitātus,{/it} past participle of {it}agitāre{/it} "to set in motion, drive before one, arouse, disturb, deal with, turn over in the mind," frequentative of {it}agere{/it} "to drive, be in motion, do, perform" {ma}{mat|agent|}{/ma}
shortdef: to excite and often trouble the mind or feelings of : disturb
to stir up public discussion of
